jeopardy_round: BUMPED FROM THE COVER OF TIME

(1, 1).clue: The movie "Kramer vs. Kramer" was pulled from the cover by the taking of U.S. hostages in this country in 1979

(2, 1).clue: Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam filled in for Jim Morrison when this group performed at its 1993 induction

(4, 1).clue: Traditionally, a married woman lights 2 candles for the sabbath just before this event on Friday

(5, 1).clue: Members on the extreme periphery of a political or social group are part of this "fringe"

(6, 1).clue: Built for Spanish trade with Asia, this Mexican city is now famous for the cliff divers of La Quebrada

(1, 2).clue: A cover titled "Declining American Birthrate" was canceled in 1974 when this man was pardoned

(2, 2).clue: "What a Wonderful World" when this jazz trumpeter was inducted for his influence on rock

(4, 2).clue: Observance of the sabbath appears on this do's-&-dont's list in Exodus 20

(5, 2).clue: It's the raising of a body into the air by supernatural means

(6, 2).clue: La Libertad is a port supplying this alliterative capital of El Salvador

(1, 3).clue: Actress Geraldine Fitzgerald made her exit from the cover when this began in 1939

(2, 3).clue: This producer famous for his "Wall of Sound" was inducted in 1989

(4, 3).clue: A portion of this scroll, whose name means "law", is read during the Saturday service

(5, 3).clue: Fishy slang term for a person who lends money at excessively high interest rates

(6, 3).clue: This Australian city was given its name by a former HMS Beagle sailor

(1, 4).clue: A Time cover called "Wonders of the Cosmos" was bumped after the assassination of this prime minister in 1995

(2, 4).clue: (Hi everybody, I'm Graham Nash.)  He was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 1988 as a group member & then in 1999 as a solo performer

(4, 4).clue: 2 loaves are blessed; the 2nd one represents the extra portion of this God gave out on Fridays in the desert

(5, 4).clue: Types of these include ovate, obovate & oblong

(6, 4).clue: If you take the last train to this Tennessee port, you'll be at the junction of the Red & Cumberland Rivers

(1, 5).clue: In 1978 a cover on black holes was sucked into oblivion with the selection of this pope, the second of 3 that year

(2, 5).clue: In 1986 the first group of inductees included Elvis Presley & this founder of Sun Records

(4, 5).clue: Title of a Shabbat hymn, or pen name of the creator of Tevye the dairyman

(5, 5).clue: This word refers to the track of one's descent from an ancestor

(6, 5).clue: 5 years as an unsold slave in this north African capital inspired Cervantes' play "El Trato de Angel"

(1, 1).clue: A controversy over interracial dating provoked an anti-one of these dances for Randolph County, Alabama students

(2, 1).clue: Lindsay Davenport said, "It really felt awesome" to win a 1996 Olympic gold medal in this sport

(3, 1).clue: In 1998 Eric Stoltz joined the cast of this medical drama as a surgeon with a background in Eastern medicine

(4, 1).clue: The annual Classic Yacht Regatta highlights a visit to this "City by the Sea"

(5, 1).clue: It can mean "large" like an oak, or precede Joe Young

(6, 1).clue: Fine port that can be drunk at once may be marked L.B.V., "Late Bottled" this

(1, 2).clue: Sergei Krikalev "found" himself the first Russian to fly on a U.S. spacecraft, this space shuttle

(2, 2).clue: Sadly, this studio fired Judy Garland after "Summer Stock" in 1950, & she never made another film there

(3, 2).clue: In 1998 Ted Danson debuted as a cranky doctor practicing in the Bronx on this show

(4, 2).clue: This chicken, the state bird, had its beginnings on a farm in Little Compton in the 1850s

(5, 2).clue: In 1961 Newton Minow described television as this type of "wasteland"

(6, 2).clue: Port got a boost from the 1703 Methuen Treaty, which gave Portuguese goods low tariffs in this country

(1, 3).clue: The U.S. got help in beating this country in World Cup soccer when Andres Escobar scored into his own net

(2, 3).clue: When some folks ask "How's Trix?", they mean this current Dutch queen (her nickname is Trix)

(3, 3).clue: In the early '80s this "Jessie's Girl" singer played Dr. Noah Drake on "General Hospital"

(4, 3).clue: University Hall at this school served as barracks for troops during the Revolutionary War

(5, 3).clue: The name of this giant Biblical animal is from Hebrew for "beasts"

(6, 3).clue: The drier white port is served as this, a French term for a drink to stimulate appetite

(2, 4).clue: In 1988 she was an indomitable 82 when she choreographed the ballet "The Informer" from her wheelchair

(5, 4).clue: In book titles it precedes e.e. cummings' "Room" & Grace Paley's "Changes at the Last Minute"

(5, 5).clue: From the same Latin root as "immeasurable", it's a 2-syllable equivalent
